source.65153144:
sns.countplot(data_kerala['Quality Parameter'])

source.b39dbae7:
sns.set_context("paper", rc={"font.size":50,"axes.titlesize":50,"axes.labelsize":50})  
sns.set(font_scale = 3)
g= sns.catplot(y="District Name", col= "Year",data =data_kerala,kind = "count",
            hue='Quality Parameter')
g.set_xticklabels(rotation=90, size=45)
g.fig.set_figwidth(60)
g.fig.set_figheight(30)
g.fig.suptitle('Analysis of Water Quality Parameter in each District by Year',size=80)
plt.show();
source.0b42208c: #### The above plot helps us to understand how the differernt physio-chemical pollutants are distributed in each district of Kerala
source.df424dbb: ### Let's Analyze State Wise. Here i'm taking the state kerala only
source.d04ea998: #### Most records in Kerala are from Palakkad and least from Kottayam
source.26c4afde:
#### These are the major physio-chemical pollutants
#### Pollutants are something (here,metal) that pollutes something (here, drinking water)
source.063ef395: #### We can see that most of the districts (11/14) reported mostly iron content and 3 districts reported more salt content.
source.9a8fd585: ### In this we can dive deep into each district or panjayat or ward to get better/clear insights.
source.4e4dd5d5: #### In kerala, the most of the records shows Iron content in water and the presence of Nitrate is comparatively low. We can also notice that no arsenic content is reported from any district of Kerala.
